events.name: An Afternoon with Marc Jones, CTO, SoftLayer
events.description: Forget Kick-starting your startup. It’s all about Zooming Ahead! Throw out those Servers, Bring in the Cloud! - Marc Jones, Chief Technology Officer, SoftLayer One of the biggest challenges for startups, no matter how brilliant the idea or, how innovative the app, is dealing with the technical side of business. Not only are you expected to get that out-of-the-box idea, plan for it, seek investors for it but you also have to seek the right technical infrastructure to take it to the masses. Well, who says you have to be technical to get that business off the ground. With everything on the cloud all you need to know about IT systems is click, point, order - and hey presto, your systems are up and running in minutes and hours, not days and months! It’s a Cloud fest - Spend time with Marc Jones as he takes us through what are the latest products in the market and what other startups are doing with the technology. Agenda: 1400 to 1415: Pre-networking 1415 to 1430: Talk by Marc Jones 1430 to 1600: Discussion + Q&A + Networking (Casual) Registration: Plugin @ NUS Enterprise Marc Jones Chief Technology Officer, SoftLayer, an IBM Company Marc Jones leads SoftLayer’s technology design and architecture teams, which focus on the development of new products and services and research and development in SoftLayer Labs. Prior to joining SoftLayer, Jones served as director of software product development for Rackspace’s cloud division.
events.location: Plugin@Blk71, 71 Ayer Rajah Crescent,  #02-18, Singapore 139951

events.name: Pivotal open source night
events.description: At this meetup we will host two technical talks about software engineering and best practices. One talk will be by - Sergiu Bodiu , a Sr. Solution Architect on the Pivotal team, about building cloud native applications. The other talk will be by Kailash Nath one of our best Hadoop expert at Pivotal Asia. Find details about both talks below: 6:45 - 7:15 :: Food and networking 7:15 - 8:45 :: Talks and Q&A 8:45 - 9:00 :: Mingling -------------- Talk Title: Build Cloud Native applications Speaker: Sergiu Bodiu, Sr. Solution Architect, Pivotal Abstract: There’s a certain “dark ages” between the waning days of Java and .Net and the renaissance we have now with PaaS and other microservices-think driven platforms. "GoldPlating" That's right, friend. Before long, you'll discover that almost any problem can be made more complicated! Tap into the unemptyable wells of PrematureComplexity & AccidentalComplexity, and have a heyday! Fortunately many of the innovators in the space, including Twitter, LinkedIn, and Netflix, have embraced the JVM as they’ve built increasingly complex systems. Spring Cloud provides tools for developers to quickly build some of the common patterns in distributed systems. Spring Boot is a micro framework for micro service applications. With the advent of microservice and cloud-native application architectures, building distributed systems is becoming increasingly common for the enterprise Java developer. About: Sergiu is a seasoned consultant experienced in large-scale e-commerce projects, passionate about providing innovative technology solutions to solve complex business problems, have extensive knowledge and experience delivering enterprise wide applications. ===================== Talk Title: "Implementing Hadoop in a large enterprise - experience sharing" Speaker: Kailash Nath, Technical Architect, Pivotal (we have interviewed Kailash here ). "Yay! I see the elephant in the room". It took a real long time for those "strategists" to accept the fact that there is an elephant in the room. How many of them really see the full elephant? Business intelligence has been used by architects for assessing architecture model and correct EA strategy all along. And so pattern like distributed computing is nothing new for them. Yet, why Hadoop/big data initiative fail or don't impress while nextgen Silicon valley enterprises make software that is eating the world using these tools? Data analytics use cases are often IT teams view of business rather than business use case defined by business users. If you don't have a big data business use case sponsored by business user, stop your project right now and save money/energy of those highly paid Hadoop experts. About: Kailash is a Technical architect with 14+ years of industry experience. Prior to joining Pivotal, he has lead the big data initiative for a large airline company and has worked 3 years on some of the largest Hadoop projects. His experience includes end to end architecture and design of large scale OLTP system like B2B e-Commerce platform, large scale integrations solutions, mobile commerce platform, high volume OLAP solutions etc.
events.location: PayPal office in Millenia Tower, 1 Temasek Avenue Millenia Tower #14-01, Singapore

events.name: Project Showcase by NUS-ISS Master of Technology in Enterprise Business Analytics Graduating Students
events.description:
You are cordially invited to a Project Showcase by our first batch of graduating students of the Master of Technology (MTech) in Enterprise Business Analytics (EBAC) programme. 
Our 40 full-time students will finish their final semester by mid-May, in time for the NUS Commencement ceremony in early July. 
All our students go through internships for eight months as part of their curriculum in the MTech programme. This is the chance for the students to apply business analytics methods and techniques to help organisations solve identified problems. 
And some of them will be showcasing the internship projects and two research projects. 
Project Showcase Details: 
Date: 10 April (Friday) Time: 8am to 2pm Venue: Institute of Systems Science, Level 2 25, Heng Mui Keng Terrace, S119615 (Click HERE for directions) 
Our MTech EBAC programme was launched in January 2014 and designed specifically to satisfy the demands of industry for practical Business Analytics skills and knowledge by developing new practitioners or upgrading entry level practitioners who have a suitable professional background, such as IT professionals. Graduates of the programme are capable of discovering insights from data, applying concepts and techniques to solve major business problems, improving decision-making to increase returns on investments for their organisation and predicting the future profitability of their organisations. Some of our graduating students have been offered roles as business analytics, data scientists and data analysts across industries like health, Infocomm, etc.  
 For more information, visit https://www.iss.nus.edu.sg/MTechEBAC/ProjectShowcase.aspx 
  
Please note that this site is not developed nor maintained by the Institute of Systems Science at the National University of Singapore (NUS-ISS).  This is a third party independent site subject to its own data protection and privacy practices and you are encouraged to examine them before proceeding to share your personal data.  NUS-ISS will collect, use and/or disclose the personal data submitted through this third party independent site for the purpose of administration and/or management of the event.

events.name: Creating and communicating with a BLE device using an Arduino, Raspberry Pi, iOS and Android by @Yeo Kheng Meng
events.description: Kheng Meng: Information about Bluetooth Low Energy(BLE) programming usually revolve around writing code on Android or iOS devices to interact with existing BLE peripherals. Very few involve actually creating your own BLE peripheral itself. After my presentation, you will get an introduction on how to program your own BLE peripheral based on an Arduino or Raspberry Pi. Basic iOS and Android BLE code will also be covered. Kheng Meng is a graduating student from NUS Comp Science faculty; he currently works at AlgoAccess, a med-tech start-up providing solutions to Opticians, Optometrists and Ophthalmologists and he enjoys innovating at the juncture of hardware and software.

events.name: Friday Hacks #92 - Web Developers' Nightmare
events.description: We'll be having three security researchers from the Ministry of Home Affairs -- Jacob, Glenn and Damian -- speaking about Web Security this week. See you! Free pizza is served before the talks. Talk description One of the main reason why there are lots of web vulnerabilities nowadays are because many developers are not trained or are not exposed to web security. This talk aims to provide a collection of common security mistakes that are found in web applications. Topics covered ranges from design mistakes to implementation mistakes. Common security vulnerabilites like Cross-Site Scripting and SQL Injection will also be discussed. This talk would help attendees gain a better understanding of these issues and hopefully help them develop more secured applications. At the end, we will also discuss about security issues surrounding NoSQL databases. Speaker profile Jacob Soo - Head of Research and Analysis Team Jacob's responsibilities include analyzing malware and carrying out security research. He is also known for his work on Android Reversing. Here, he served as head of software security and was in charge of the malware analysis framework and is responsible for both monitoring the regional malware situation and in-depth analysis of cyber incidents. Damian Ong - Senior Security Researcher, Research and Analysis Team Damian is responsible for monitoring the malware threat landscape. He specializes in web security, malware, and threats which target Government systems, including phishing. He is involved in several innovative research projects, ranging from malware databases or honeypots to web crawlers. Glenn Ng - Senior Security Researcher, Research and Analysis Team Glenn is a specialist in cyber and advanced persistent threats and defense, penetration testing, malware landscape. He mostly focuses on reverse-engineering and in-depth analysis of contemporary advanced threats. His area of interest includes analysing exploits for Windows systems and embedded platforms. Our Sponsors Friday Hacks is sponsored by the NUS Enterprise Center and the Infocomm Development Authority. If you are looking to turn your ideas into a startup and would love some business support, feel free to get in touch with Jason from NUS Enterprise: jasontgw@nus.edu.sg
events.location: SR3, Town Plaza, UTown

events.name: TGIFHacks #34 - Annual General Meeting 2015
events.description: We are now nearing the end of another semester that brings with it the end of another academic year. At the Open Source Society (OSS), it also means the end of term for the present Management Committee. Over the past year, we have done our best to make our club a good platform for students to learn skills outside of the curriculum, demonstrate their capacity for invention, connect with other technically inclined and like-minded people and with the industry. We have worked towards that vision via TGIFHacks, a weekly series of workshops, project demonstrations and company talks. Through TGIFHacks, we hope to achieve our long term objective of being a student community helping to attract students of common technical interests to foster a community of engineers, hackers and builders to explore their interests in technology and share their knowledge and expertise with others. This Friday, at our last TGIFHacks for this semester we will be having our final event, the Annual General Meeting 2015, in order to select the next batch of leaders, who will guide the club in future. As a member of the OSS, we believe that you should have a say in your expectations from the club. Therefore, we would like to invite you to this year’s AGM 2015 to help us choose the new Management Committee whom you think will be able to take the OSS to greater heights. Details of the event are as follows: Date: Friday, 10 April 2015 Time: 6.30pm onwards Venue: TR+37 Drinks and snacks will be served. Please indicate your attendance here so that we can make provisions. We would like to thank you for your continued support of the OSS and its activities throughout the year and we look forward to seeing you at the AGM 2015.
events.location: TR+37

events.name: Apr/2015 - Open Space (Development Practices & Craftsmanship)

Issues of interest to polyglot programmers also encouraged. • Software Craftsmanship , including code quality, fundamental creation practices, multi-paradigm programming, responding to change, reducing rework, making the most of a career in software development, and learning how to build better software. • In-depth technical topics , including async programming, developing for and with the cloud, continuous anything, and interesting data topics are all highly valued. More information can be found from the Agile2015 AgileAlliance website . Agenda 7:00pm - Food 7:30pm - Generate topics and schedule 8:00pm - Breakout to topic sessions 10:00pm - End We welcome contributions of drinks and snacks! =) What is Open Space? Open Space is a highly collaborative and self-organised meeting where topics are generated on the spot and discussed by the participants through breakout sessions. For more information read Open Space Technology . Getting There Marina Bay Financial Centre Tower 2 is just right above of Downtown station along Downtown Line (DT) .

events.name: Docker Open-Source-a-thon
events.description: The Docker Project, the open platform for distributed applications, is organizing an open-source-a-thon. The Docker Project, the open platform for distributed applications, announced it will be organizing an open-source-a-thon where Docker core team members will teach and mentor people in how to contribute to open source. Contributions include code, documentation, tutorials, videos, and mentoring. Each contribution to the Docker Project will also support the Oceanic Society and its mission to conserve oceans. https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/9TUPu8HhBrr7DIDpX1o96dkM3SpW0py7zmVwq6PpCFw807kV-huO0IOA4gCN3rnUf7ldUT8nG89c7xn8dUPkRczicz2Ep597ydj4BSfRabK3Z2J_oaIXUJ0JLeoY9Dsp_COhDxc The program is timed to coincide with the project’s 2nd birthday and is focused on a cause – ocean and marine life health – that is important to its millions of users. Docker’s logo, Moby Dock, is a blue whale that was contributed and selected by its community. The charitable program starts on March 23 and will span a total of five weeks; part of the proceeds will go towards the adoption and naming of a female blue whale soon to be known as “Molly Dock.” Contributions from the “opening week” of the program and follow-on contributions over the subsequent four weeks will be calculated and the final donation will be made. One contribution equates to a $50 donation, and an additional $50 will be added to the “Molly Dock fund” for those that wish to continue to contribute. As we get closer to the event, more information will be added to docker.party ! Agenda: 3:00 - Doors Open 3:15 to 3:45 - Introduction & Presentation on contributing to the Docker Open Source project 3:45 to 7:30 - Break out into groups. 1) Non code contributions 2) Beginner Code contributions (either new to Go or Docker) 3) Advanced Code contributions (advanced users are encouraged to mentor #2 as well) 7:30 to 8:00 Snacks and socializing Sponsors

events.name: Future Of Health
events.description:
The Future of Health event will feature 2 speakers focusing on how technological advances are bringing about changes that will impact our health. 
  
1. What is wrong with healthcare?  By: Balaji Venkatesan 
Balaji Venkatesan is currently heading product development for Zuellig Pharma Patient solutions. 
Balaji is a staunch believer in the transformational nature of technology. Transformation of individuals and organizations are his key areas of interest. He has over 20 years of experience in business and technology. He is constantly looking for new ways in which technology can benefit businesses and individuals.An active participant in the QS, Futurists & other tech groups. 
In this talk, Balaji will give a view into the many areas in which exponential technology is revolutionizing health-care. 
2. Transformation of healthcare By:  Julien de Salaberry 
Julien is the founder of The Propell Group and has over 15 years of experience in healthcare with leading brands including Eli Lilly, Boston Scientific, Baxter, GSK, Merck&Co. He is also an advisor to startups and incubators in healthcare and technology in emerging high growth markets as well as being a private investor in early stage and promising SMEs. 
Julien has recently co-written iDisrupted (published in November 2014), which focuses on creating an understanding of the significant technological changes that, are just beginning to re-shape our daily lives. 
He is also, together with his partners, currently launching HealthStartups Asia, which aims to create greater momentum in the Asia healthtech space by raising the visibility of exciting new startups which have set out to transform health services by leveraging digital technology in the Asia-Pacific markets. 
Julien will provide a deeper look into the digital health space, in particular how sensors, algorithms and data are transforming health-care.
events.location: IDA Labs @ National Design Centre, , 111 Middle Rd, #03-04, Singapore 188969

events.name: HackerNest Singapore April Tech Social
events.description:
The long-and-short: Tech Socials are powered by awesome volunteer organizers that are passionate about community-building. 
Easy as pie. And, our whole team is involved in making sure you start with a blast and make awesome stuff happen! Please read the FAQ on our continually broken/changing site and GET IN TOUCH if you or someone you know might be interested. 
--------> 
Drinks on us. That's right: free beer/(possibly wine)/water. 
 
HackerNest Tech Socials are a fun, relaxed way to connect with your local tech brethren. Atmosphere: chill, friendly, unpretentious, agenda-free (no sales pitch, yo), and brimming with UltraSmart(TM) people. 
We believe that strong, supportive tech communities should exist everywhere - not just in hotspots like San Francisco and New York. In 2011, we started running Tech Socials in Toronto, where our monthly attendance grew to over 350+ technologists literally 100% from word-of-mouth. 
The typical Tech Social schedule: 
- 6:30pm: folks arrive, grab drinks, socialize   - 7:00pm: quick intro, thank sponsors, quick announcements   - 7:10pm: back to chatting with interesting new friends   - 9:00pm: go home exhausted from great conversations 
Sponsors make this growing movement possible - email us to chat! 
Venue: 
Zopim: Talk to your customers in real time 
 
Wanna show off your office? We're always looking for big open spaces with 50+ (standing room) capacity that are easily accessible. 
About Us: 
HackerNest is an international nonprofit uniting local tech communities through unpretentious Tech Socials and hackathons. We cram lots of smart, accomplished people into a room with free drinks. Our relaxed, down-to-earth events attract a diverse and highly technical membership. Strict no-douchebag policy.
events.location: Zopim, , 401 Commonwealth Drive, Haw Par Technocentre, #07-01, 149598, Singapore null

events.description: For this instalment of Creative Coding Meetup, we have three presenters lined up, namely George Gally, Daniel Wessolek and Cedric Honnet. George Gally http://radarboy.com/george/ is [ironcially] a coding denier/artist, and is enthusiastic about a wide range of artistics expressions dominated by technology and real world analogue interactions. George will be touching upon the topic of motion and audio reactive in Javascript. Daniel Wessolek http://danielwessolek.com/port/ works as a research associate in Interaction Design at Bauhaus University Weimar. events.name: Brief History of Lean
events.description: Kiro Harada , a lean veteran, will be in Singapore to run a workshop on Scrum and Kaizen . He kindly agreed to give a talk about the History of Lean and run a short workshop. We are still looking for a pizza sponsor for this meetup! ------ Lean has become a de-facto standard of managing complex systems. But how was it developed? How has it evolved over decades? In this talk and small workshop, we try to capture the whole picture of lean. Especially, we put emphasis on understanding the production side and the developing side of lean. We also talk about Kanban history and why limited WIP is for push systems.

events.name: SCADA security, Hardcore stuff i hack and Encrypted Databases in Cloud
events.description: Hi folks, we will have our null Singapore, Monthly meet up on Tuesday i.e., 14th April 2015. Agenda ( 40 min talk each) : Introduction to Null singapore ( 10 mins ) by Imran Vulnerability Assessments on SCADA Systems – Outsmarting the Smart Grid by Fadli B. Sidek Encrypted Databases for Untrusted Cloud by Vasily Sidorov The Hardcore Stuff I Hack by Paul Craig ( Order of the talk might vary ) Abstract of the talk(s): Encrypted Databases for Untrusted Cloud 1. security threats we face in the cloud 2. common approaches to database security 3. challenges of operating an encrypted database 4. how it can be done and what is the price of security in this case The Hardcore Stuff I Hack: This talk is going to give a run through of some of the technical challenges myself and my team have overcome over the years - in as much hardcore detail as possible. Vulnerability Assessments on SCADA Systems – Outsmarting the Smart Grid : SCADA assessments has been on the news and the talk of the town since 2005. While there are many talks and demonstrations about how to penetrate and exploit SCADA systems, little discussions about the pre-exploitation phase were being shared and discussed. In this talk, i am going to share my experience on how i performed my assessment for a huge smart grid facility consisting of more than 30 sites. I will cover how i did the assessment for both onsite as well as remote and how i accidentally brought down a whole operation center. This talk will also share the lessons learned and how to develop a proper methodology and process in performing vulnerability assessment on a network of SCADA systems. Speaker(s) Bio: Fadli B. Sidek is a Cyber Security enthusiast and currently working at a security company specializing in application security. His experience include performing vulnerability assessments and penetration testing to clients in the AMEA region. He graduated from Murdoch University, Australia with a Double Majors Degree in Cyber Forensics, Information Security Management and Business Information System. He has over 9 years of experience in IT and Security and has written and published security articles in Pentestmag and Hakin9 and has spoken at several security conferences in Singapore, India, UAE, Europe and the U.S. Paul Craig, I lead a technical boutique security team in Singapore focusing on hacking "everything with a flashing light" for some of the largest brand companies in Singapore. I've been doing it like this for 11 years, and as i often say "Hacking is the only thing i do well". This talk is going to give a run through of some of the technical challenges myself and my team have overcome over the years - in as much hardcore detail as possible. Vasily Sidorov is a researcher and PhD candidate with Data-Intensive Scalable Computng (DISCO) Lab at Nanyang Technological University, Sch. of Comp. Eng., since 2011. Was awarded a MOE AcRF Tier 1 research grant for his project. Holds MSc degree in Maths and CompSci, and another MSc degree in Business Mgmt and HR, both from Lomonosov Moscow State University, Russia Follow us on twitter @nullsingapore. - Null Singapore

events.name: How to measure user experience and reduce abandonment by more than 30%
events.description:
Whether you are well established e-Commerce brand such as Zalora, Agoda or a small business with a web shop, it’s never too late to gain more insights into your customers’ end user experience to make better decisions on where next to spend engineering and marketing money. 
With the establishment of mobile web and native mobile apps, your website isn't the only customer touch point anymore and it is critical to deliver the same user experience across all the channels (Mobile App/Mobile Web/Web). 
 In order to do that you need to find a way to monitor and measure user experience across your delivery channels to allow both business and engineers to make the right decisions on where to invest time and money to improve user experience. 
Join us, as Andreas Grabner, Technology Strategist at Dynatrace, shares best practices from different global companies and learn:   
- which metrics you really need to monitor across your channels  
-how to make data-driven decisions based on these metrics  

-changing your deployment model of applications and new features to become metric driven and not just demand driven 
  
This event is supported by Mobile Monday SIngapore.
events.location: The Penny Black, , 27 Boat Quay, Singapore 049817

events.name: Mobile App Monitoring without Code Changes
events.description: <Mobile App Monitoring without Code Changes>/ How to measure user experience and reduce abandonment by more than 30% What if you can automatically capture user actions, network requests, and crashes, giving you all the information you need to know on your user experience? Reduces the complexity of manual instrumentation by automatically adding the instrumentation for lifecycle actions and network tagging Join us, as Andreas Grabner, Technology Strategist at Dynatrace, shares best practices from different global companies and learn: - which metrics you really need to monitor across your channels -how to make data-driven decisions based on these metrics -changing your deployment model of applications and new features to become metric driven and not just demand driven

events.name: Book Club: High Performance Websites
events.description: The weekly SingaporeJS book club is back! This time we will be reading the book High Performance Web Sites together and creating interactive exercises to go along with it. Join the SingaporeJS Chat Bookclub for the 14th of April: Chapter 3, Chapter 4, Chapter 5. Michael skipped ahead and gave us a great overview of Chapters 3 and 4 at the previous meetup, so let's make sure everyone has read them plus Chapter 5. Here is the description about the book: Want your web site to display more quickly? This book presents 14 specific rules that will cut 25% to 50% off response time when users request a page. Author Steve Souders, in his job as Chief Performance Yahoo!, collected these best practices while optimizing some of the most-visited pages on the Web. Even sites that had already been highly optimized, such as Yahoo! Search and the Yahoo! Front Page, were able to benefit from these surprisingly simple performance guidelines. The rules in High Performance Web Sites explain how you can optimize the performance of the Ajax, CSS, JavaScript, Flash, and images that you've already built into your site -- adjustments that are critical for any rich web application. Other sources of information pay a lot of attention to tuning web servers, databases, and hardware, but the bulk of display time is taken up on the browser side and by the communication between server and browser. High Performance Web Sites covers every aspect of that process. Format for the book club: 1. Buy the book and read the Chapter (s) BEFORE the meetup. 2. Pick an Item from the Chapter and prepare some discussion points and/or questions. 3. Let the rest of us know which Item you picked by leaving a comment. We will be reading at Tim & Wei's residence at Tanjong Katong Road. Door opens at 6.30pm. Feel free to ask questions in the SingaporeJS Chat Room See you there!
events.location: Tim & Wei's Residence, 244A Tanjong Katong Road, Singapore

events.name: DataDive: Earth Hour and HOME
events.description: Calling all socially conscious analysts, statisticians, data scientists, coders, hackers and designers! Come join us for a weekend of working with data to do good! RSVP to work alongside experts in the field to analyze, visualize, and mash-up the data from our non-profit partners. If we don't know you already, please tell us a bit more about yourself by filling in this Google form ! Non-Profit Organizations 1) Earth Hour World Wildlife Fund ’s Earth Hour is a global environmental movement with a core vision to create environmental impact by utilizing the power of the crowd. Started seven years ago, Earth Hour has grown to become the world’s largest mass participation event in history: celebrated in over 7,000 cities, across 7 continents and by hundreds of millions of people. Earth Hour recently took place around the world on 28 Mar 2015 (Sat, 8.30 - 9.30 pm). 2) Humanitarian Organisation for Migration Economics (HOME) Founded in 2004, the Humanitarian Organization for Migration Economics (HOME) serves the needs of the migrant worker community in Singapore by developing research and education on the socioeconomics of migration in Singapore and the countries of origin, providing social integration services for emigrants and immigrants, and providing humanitarian assistance for the effects of 'crisis' migration. There are more than 1.3 million documented migrant workers or more in Singapore, of which about 1.1 million are low-wage workers. HOME has provided services to more than 50,000 migrant workers through its provision of shelters, legal assistance, health education training and rehabilitative services. Special thanks to Fuji Xerox Singapore for being our venue sponsor! Schedule Friday, Apr 24th 7.15 pm: Doors open, sign-in (we're on the 4th floor!) 7.45 pm: Introduction to Non-Profit Organizations and Datasets 8.15 pm: Pitching for teams 8.30 pm: Formation of teams It's a great chance to learn about the non-profits and their data, meet the other volunteers you'll be working and talk with others from our partner causes. Plus, there will be snacks and drinks! Saturday, Apr 25th 9 am: Doors open, sign-in and breakfast 9.30 am: Brief review from Data Ambassadors, then data diving! 12.30 pm: Lunch 1 pm: Open Roundtables 6 pm: Dinner 9 pm: Everybody goes home for the night Saturday we'll start work on the data! DataDivers will choose which problems they'd like to work on and form teams around their individual questions. There will be roving DataKind project team leads who will help advise on and manage the projects throughout the day. Sunday, Apr 26th 9 am: Doors open, breakfast 12 noon: Presentations from teams to social organizations 2 pm: Another successful DataDive in the books! This is your chance to show the world what you have done with data! There is no expectation of slides or other presentation materials, simply use whatever method of conveying your work to the organizations you feel is best. This is also the chance for our non-profit partners to better understand what your team did. These presentations can be single or group work, but they can be no longer than 10 minutes each. We want to give everyone a chance to speak, and get people out at a reasonable time. Other items of note for the weekend Volunteers at all levels are welcome throughout the weekend . If you're already a pro, we're looking for some subject-area experts to help with project preparation and be resources throughout the DataDive. Unlike a hackathon, the goal is not (necessarily) to create an app, and it is not a competition. Instead, the objective is to work with teams of experts to understand a truly difficult problem through data. You could end up with a visualization, an analysis, some graphs, or even just some new datasets by the end of the event, and all of those are fantastic results! There is a Github repository setup to use for sharing code and analyses during the event . This will be our primary resource for capturing everything developed at the DataDive, so please use it for sharing and collaboration. We do not assign you to a problem . We want you to work with the problem and data you feel most passionate about, so come Friday with an open mind and be ready to learn. You do not have to stay the entire weekend to participate in the event . We hope that you will find a project you can dig into, but you are always welcome to come and go as you please. You do not have to work on the same project for the whole weekend . Again, we hope that you will find a project to work on to completion, but if at any point you feel like you want to change simply let the DataKind project team lead for your team know. We do not provide any hardware or software for you to use . We'll have the data and some services set up (hackpad, Github), but otherwise you should bring your own laptop and come ready to use whatever data tools you like. See you there!

Bookclub for the 14th of April: Chapter 3, Chapter 4, Chapter 5. Michael skipped ahead and gave us a great overview of Chapters 3 and 4 at the previous meetup, so let's make sure everyone has read them plus Chapter 5. Here is the description about the book: Want your web site to display more quickly? This book presents 14 specific rules that will cut 25% to 50% off response time when users request a page. Author Steve Souders, in his job as Chief Performance Yahoo!, collected these best practices while optimizing some of the most-visited pages on the Web. Even sites that had already been highly optimized, such as Yahoo! Search and the Yahoo! Front Page, were able to benefit from these surprisingly simple performance guidelines. The rules in High Performance Web Sites explain how you can optimize the performance of the Ajax, CSS, JavaScript, Flash, and images that you've already built into your site -- adjustments that are critical for any rich web application. Other sources of information pay a lot of attention to tuning web servers, databases, and hardware, but the bulk of display time is taken up on the browser side and by the communication between server and browser. High Performance Web Sites covers every aspect of that process. Format for the book club: 1. Buy the book and read the Chapter (s) BEFORE the meetup. 2. Pick an Item from the Chapter and prepare some discussion points and/or questions. 3. Let the rest of us know which Item you picked by leaving a comment. events.location: ArtScience Museum

events.name: Nurturing Leonardos
events.description: Nurturing Leonardos An international conference Friday 8 and Saturday 9 May 2015 Expression Gallery, Level 4 FREE On 8 and 9 May 2015, ArtScience Museum will host a conference exploring the legacy of history's most celebrated artist and scientist, Leonardo da Vinci (1452-1519). Most studies of da Vinci focus on a specific area of his activity - art, anatomy, technology, studies on water, on flight, and so on. This conference will offer a different point of view, encouraging an exploration of da Vinci's way of thinking and of the cultural landscape, which nurtured him. It will analyze how his interdisciplinary approach, which we now refer to as “systems thinking” and "complexity", remains strikingly resonant for us today, and applied within the fields of art, science, technology, architecture and foresight. The conference begins with a special edition of ArtScience Museum's monthly performance programme, ArtScience late (Thursday 7 May), and continues for two full days of discussions on 8-9 May, featuring presentations from within Singapore and around the world, from a range of leading speakers in the fields of science, history, technology, and architecture. The conference chairs are Honor Harger (ArtScience Museum) and Andrea Nanetti (Nanyang Technological University, School of Art, Design and Media and Complexity Institute). Thursday 7 May 2015 7.00 - 10.00pm: ArtScience Late with a special performance from TeZ, our international ArtScience resident. Friday 8 May 2015 10:00am - 7.00pm The first day of the conference presents da Vinci and the approach that he took to all of his lines of enquiries. It analyses how da Vinci not only understood the essence of ‘systems’ thinking, but how he also applied this to his inventions, ideas and work generally. We ask, was this approach extraordinary for its time? Was da Vinci different from his renowned contemporaries in this way? To address these questions, the keynote speaker, Professor Galluzzi will present an overview of da Vinci’s life, influences, influencers and projects in this context, and Professor Fiorani will explore the educational context of da Vinci’s time and place. We will explore if there was something within the context of da Vinci’s time which encouraged his thinking and ‘systems’ awareness, or was this a one-off – a spike in the linear progression of epistemology? We ask if there are there other examples of interdisciplinary thinking and approaches throughout history. The day will continue with a reflection on the more recent times and the advent of new media – a marriage of two seemingly quite separate, established disciplines: art and technology, moving the dialogue into the 20th century, and beyond. Saturday, 9 May 2015 10:00am - 7.00pm The whistle-stop tour through key ‘systems thinkers’ in history from the previous day, which ended with a look at innovation today in Singapore, continues with a day exploring contemporary ‘systems approaches’, specifically addressing the areas of: education and pedagogical methodologies today; and how science and technology can be applied broadly to work through some of the world’s most pressing issues. Fittingly, the last session looks to the future, and how ‘systems thinking’ is being successfully used to address environmental issues – perhaps the biggest threat to the continuing survival of the planet and its inhabitants. And where is Singapore within this landscape? Confirmed participants include: Paolo Galluzzi (Italy) Alberto Rocca (Italy) David Harvey (USA) Francesca Fiorani (USA) Gunalan Nadarajan (Singapore/USA) Luciano Chessa (Italy/USA) Ruben De La Nuez (Singapore) Vibeke Sorensen (Singapore) Justin Pickard (UK) Tit Meng Lim (Singapore) Noorlinah Mohamed (Singapore) Forum for the Future More speakers to be announced.
events.location: ArtScience Museum

events.name: Book Club: High Performance Websites
events.description: The weekly SingaporeJS book club is back! This time we will be reading the book High Performance Web Sites together and creating interactive exercises to go along with it. Bookclub for the 14th of April: Chapter 3, Chapter 4, Chapter 5. Michael skipped ahead and gave us a great overview of Chapters 3 and 4 at the previous meetup, so let's make sure everyone has read them plus Chapter 5. Here is the description about the book: Want your web site to display more quickly? This book presents 14 specific rules that will cut 25% to 50% off response time when users request a page. Author Steve Souders, in his job as Chief Performance Yahoo!, collected these best practices while optimizing some of the most-visited pages on the Web. Even sites that had already been highly optimized, such as Yahoo! Search and the Yahoo! Front Page, were able to benefit from these surprisingly simple performance guidelines. The rules in High Performance Web Sites explain how you can optimize the performance of the Ajax, CSS, JavaScript, Flash, and images that you've already built into your site -- adjustments that are critical for any rich web application. Other sources of information pay a lot of attention to tuning web servers, databases, and hardware, but the bulk of display time is taken up on the browser side and by the communication between server and browser. High Performance Web Sites covers every aspect of that process. Format for the book club: 1. Buy the book and read the Chapter (s) BEFORE the meetup. 2. Pick an Item from the Chapter and prepare some discussion points and/or questions. 3. Let the rest of us know which Item you picked by leaving a comment. We will be reading at Tim & Wei's residence at Tanjong Katong Road. Door opens at 6.30pm. Feel free to ask questions in the SingaporeJS gitter room: https://gitter.im/SingaporeJS/discussions See you there!
events.location: Tim & Wei's Residence, 244A Tanjong Katong Road, Singapore

events.name: Hebocon Singapore (Robotics competition for the technically ungifted)
events.description: We will be holding a HEBOCON challenge as part of the South East Asia Makerspace Summit scheduled to be held from 5-7 June 2015. Known as Japan’s "worst robot competition”, the purpose of the HEBOCON event is to find out which crappy robot is the ultimate failure of them all through a sumo-styled wrestling battle. This event will serve as a testbed for the organizers to improve the competition processes leading to the HEBOCON main event in July. Thank you. For more information about HEBOCON, check out the official page at https://www.facebook.com/Hebocon.Official

events.name: Book Club: High Performance Websites
events.description: The weekly SingaporeJS book club is back! This time we will be reading the book High Performance Web Sites together and creating interactive exercises to go along with it. Bookclub for the 14th of April: Chapter 3, Chapter 4, Chapter 5. Michael skipped ahead and gave us a great overview of Chapters 3 and 4 at the previous meetup, so let's make sure everyone has read them plus Chapter 5. Here is the description about the book: Want your web site to display more quickly? This book presents 14 specific rules that will cut 25% to 50% off response time when users request a page. Author Steve Souders, in his job as Chief Performance Yahoo!, collected these best practices while optimizing some of the most-visited pages on the Web. Even sites that had already been highly optimized, such as Yahoo! Search and the Yahoo! Front Page, were able to benefit from these surprisingly simple performance guidelines. The rules in High Performance Web Sites explain how you can optimize the performance of the Ajax, CSS, JavaScript, Flash, and images that you've already built into your site -- adjustments that are critical for any rich web application. Other sources of information pay a lot of attention to tuning web servers, databases, and hardware, but the bulk of display time is taken up on the browser side and by the communication between server and browser. High Performance Web Sites covers every aspect of that process. Format for the book club: 1. Buy the book and read the Chapter (s) BEFORE the meetup. 2. Pick an Item from the Chapter and prepare some discussion points and/or questions. 3. Let the rest of us know which Item you picked by leaving a comment. We will be reading at Tim & Wei's residence at Tanjong Katong Road. Door opens at 6.30pm. Feel free to ask questions in the SingaporeJS gitter room: https://gitter.im/SingaporeJS/discussions See you there!
events.location: Tim & Wei's Residence, 244A Tanjong Katong Road, Singapore

events.name: Book Club: High Performance Websites
events.description: The weekly SingaporeJS book club is back! This time we will be reading the book High Performance Web Sites together and creating interactive exercises to go along with it. Bookclub for the 14th of April: Chapter 3, Chapter 4, Chapter 5. Michael skipped ahead and gave us a great overview of Chapters 3 and 4 at the previous meetup, so let's make sure everyone has read them plus Chapter 5. Here is the description about the book: Want your web site to display more quickly? This book presents 14 specific rules that will cut 25% to 50% off response time when users request a page. Author Steve Souders, in his job as Chief Performance Yahoo!, collected these best practices while optimizing some of the most-visited pages on the Web. Even sites that had already been highly optimized, such as Yahoo! Search and the Yahoo! Front Page, were able to benefit from these surprisingly simple performance guidelines. The rules in High Performance Web Sites explain how you can optimize the performance of the Ajax, CSS, JavaScript, Flash, and images that you've already built into your site -- adjustments that are critical for any rich web application. Other sources of information pay a lot of attention to tuning web servers, databases, and hardware, but the bulk of display time is taken up on the browser side and by the communication between server and browser. High Performance Web Sites covers every aspect of that process. Format for the book club: 1. Buy the book and read the Chapter (s) BEFORE the meetup. 2. Pick an Item from the Chapter and prepare some discussion points and/or questions. 3. Let the rest of us know which Item you picked by leaving a comment. We will be reading at Tim & Wei's residence at Tanjong Katong Road. Door opens at 6.30pm. Feel free to ask questions in the SingaporeJS gitter room: https://gitter.im/SingaporeJS/discussions See you there!
events.location: Tim & Wei's Residence, 244A Tanjong Katong Road, Singapore
